21.18: When men quarrel and one strikes the other with a stone or with his fist, not mortally, but enough to put him in bed,
21.19: the one who struck the blow shall be acquitted, provided the other can get up and walk around with the help of his staff. Still, he must compensate him for his recovery time and make provision for his complete healing.
21.20: When someone strikes his male or female slave with a rod so that the slave dies under his hand, the act shall certainly be avenged.
21.21: If, however, the slave survives for a day or two, he is not to be punished, since the slave is his own property.
21.22: When men have a fight and hurt a pregnant woman, so that she suffers a miscarriage, but no further injury, the guilty one shall be fined as much as the woman’s husband demands of him, and he shall pay in the presence of the judges.
21.23: But if injury ensues, you shall give life for life,
21.24: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
21.25: burn for burn, wound for wound, stripe for stripe.
21.26: When someone strikes his male or female slave in the eye and destroys the use of the eye, he shall let the slave go free in compensation for the eye.
21.27: If he knocks out a tooth of his male or female slave, he shall let the slave go free in compensation for the tooth.
21.28: When an ox gores a man or a woman to death, the ox must be stoned; its meat may not be eaten. The owner of the ox, however, shall be free of blame.
21.29: But if an ox was previously in the habit of goring people and its owner, though warned, would not watch it; should it then kill a man or a woman, not only must the ox be stoned, but its owner also must be put to death.
21.30: If, however, a fine is imposed on him, he must pay in ransom for his life whatever amount is imposed on him.
21.31: This ordinance applies if it is a boy or a girl that the ox gores.
21.32: But if it is a male or a female slave that it gores, he must pay the owner of the slave thirty shekels of silver, and the ox must be stoned.
21.33: Property Damage. When someone uncovers or digs a cistern and does not cover it over again, should an ox or a donkey fall into it,
21.34: the owner of the cistern must make good by restoring the value of the animal to its owner, but the dead animal he may keep.
21.35: When one man’s ox hurts another’s ox and it dies, they shall sell the live ox and divide this money as well as the dead animal equally between them.
21.36: But if it was known that the ox was previously in the habit of goring and its owner would not watch it, he must make full restitution, an ox for an ox; but the dead animal he may keep.
21.37: When someone steals an ox or a sheep and slaughters or sells it, he shall restore five oxen for the one ox, and four sheep for the one sheep.

22.1: Chapter 22 - [If a thief is caught in the act of housebreaking and beaten to death, there is no bloodguilt involved.
22.2: But if after sunrise he is thus beaten, there is bloodguilt.] He must make full restitution. If he has nothing, he shall be sold to pay for his theft.
22.3: If what he stole is found alive in his possession, be it an ox, a donkey or a sheep, he shall make twofold restitution.
22.4: When someone causes a field or a vineyard to be grazed over, by sending his cattle to graze in another’s field, he must make restitution with the best produce of his own field or vineyard.
22.5: If a fire breaks out, catches on to thorn bushes, and consumes shocked grain, standing grain, or the field itself, the one who started the fire must make full restitution.
22.6: Trusts and Loans. When someone gives money or articles to another for safekeeping and they are stolen from the latter’s house, the thief, if caught, must make twofold restitution.
22.7: If the thief is not caught, the owner of the house shall be brought to God, to swear that he himself did not lay hands on his neighbor’s property.
22.8: In every case of dishonest appropriation, whether it be about an ox, or a donkey, or a sheep, or a garment, or anything else that has disappeared, where another claims that the thing is his, the claim of both parties shall be brought before God; the one whom God convicts must make twofold restitution to the other.
22.9: When someone gives an ass, or an ox, or a sheep, or any other animal to another for safekeeping, if it dies, or is maimed or snatched away, without anyone witnessing the fact,
22.10: there shall be an oath before the LORD between the two of them that the guardian did not lay hands on his neighbor’s property; the owner must accept the oath, and no restitution is to be made.
22.11: But if the guardian has actually stolen from it, then he must make restitution to the owner.
22.12: If it has been killed by a wild beast, let him bring it as evidence; he need not make restitution for the mangled animal.
22.13: When someone borrows an animal from a neighbor, if it is maimed or dies while the owner is not present, that one must make restitution.
22.14: But if the owner is present, that one need not make restitution. If it was hired, this was covered by the price of its hire.
22.15: Social Laws. When a man seduces a virgin who is not betrothed, and lies with her, he shall make her his wife by paying the bride price.
22.16: If her father refuses to give her to him, he must still pay him the bride price for virgins.
22.17: You shall not let a woman who practices sorcery live.
22.18: Anyone who lies with an animal shall be put to death.
22.19: Whoever sacrifices to any god, except to the LORD alone, shall be put under the ban.
22.20: You shall not oppress or afflict a resident alien, for you were once aliens residing in the land of Egypt.
22.21: You shall not wrong any widow or orphan.
22.22: If ever you wrong them and they cry out to me, I will surely listen to their cry.
22.23: My wrath will flare up, and I will kill you with the sword; then your own wives will be widows, and your children orphans.
22.24: If you lend money to my people, the poor among you, you must not be like a money lender; you must not demand interest from them.
22.25: If you take your neighbor’s cloak as a pledge, you shall return it to him before sunset;
22.26: for this is his only covering; it is the cloak for his body. What will he sleep in? If he cries out to me, I will listen; for I am compassionate.
22.27: You shall not despise God, nor curse a leader of your people.
22.28: You shall not delay the offering of your harvest and your press. You shall give me the firstborn of your sons.
22.29: You must do the same with your oxen and your sheep; for seven days the firstling may stay with its mother, but on the eighth day you must give it to me.
22.30: You shall be a people sacred to me. Flesh torn to pieces in the field you shall not eat; you must throw it to the dogs.

23.1: Chapter 23 - You shall not repeat a false report. Do not join your hand with the wicked to be a witness supporting violence.
23.2: You shall not follow the crowd in doing wrong. When testifying in a lawsuit, you shall not follow the crowd in perverting justice.
23.3: You shall not favor the poor in a lawsuit.
23.4: When you come upon your enemy’s ox or donkey going astray, you must see to it that it is returned.
23.5: When you notice the donkey of one who hates you lying down under its burden, you should not desert him; you must help him with it.
23.6: You shall not pervert justice for the needy among you in a lawsuit.
23.7: You shall keep away from anything dishonest. The innocent and the just you shall not put to death, for I will not acquit the guilty.
23.8: Never take a bribe, for a bribe blinds the clear-sighted and distorts the words of the just.
23.9: You shall not oppress a resident alien; you well know how it feels to be an alien, since you were once aliens yourselves in the land of Egypt.
23.10: Religious Laws. For six years you may sow your land and gather in its produce.
23.11: But the seventh year you shall let the land lie untilled and fallow, that the poor of your people may eat of it and their leftovers the wild animals may eat. So also shall you do in regard to your vineyard and your olive grove.
23.12: For six days you may do your work, but on the seventh day you must rest, that your ox and your donkey may have rest, and that the son of your maidservant and the resident alien may be refreshed.
23.13: Give heed to all that I have told you. You shall not mention the name of any other god; it shall not be heard from your lips.
23.14: Three times a year you shall celebrate a pilgrim feast to me.
23.15: You shall keep the feast of Unleavened Bread. As I have commanded you, you must eat unleavened bread for seven days at the appointed time in the month of Abib, for it was then that you came out of Egypt. No one shall appear before me empty-handed.
23.16: You shall also keep the feast of the grain harvest with the first fruits of the crop that you sow in the field; and finally, the feast of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you collect your produce from the fields.
23.17: Three times a year shall all your men appear before the LORD God.
23.18: You shall not offer the blood of my sacrifice with anything leavened; nor shall the fat of my feast be kept overnight till the next day.
23.19: The choicest first fruits of your soil you shall bring to the house of the LORD, your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.
23.20: Reward of Fidelity. See, I am sending an angel before you, to guard you on the way and bring you to the place I have prepared.
23.21: Be attentive to him and obey him. Do not rebel against him, for he will not forgive your sin. My authority is within him.
23.22: If you obey him and carry out all I tell you, I will be an enemy to your enemies and a foe to your foes.
23.23: My angel will go before you and bring you to the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hivites and Jebusites; and I will wipe them out.
23.24: Therefore, you shall not bow down to their gods and serve them, nor shall you act as they do; rather, you must demolish them and smash their sacred stones.
23.25: You shall serve the LORD, your God; then he will bless your food and drink, and I will remove sickness from your midst;
23.26: no woman in your land will be barren or miscarry; and I will give you a full span of life.
23.27: I will have the terror of me precede you, so that I will throw into panic every nation you reach. I will make all your enemies turn from you in flight,
23.28: and ahead of you I will send hornets to drive the Hivites, Canaanites and Hittites out of your way.
23.29: But I will not drive them all out before you in one year, lest the land become desolate and the wild animals multiply against you.
23.30: Little by little I will drive them out before you, until you have grown numerous enough to take possession of the land.
23.31: I will set your boundaries from the Red Sea to the sea of the Philistines, and from the wilderness to the Euphrates; all who dwell in this land I will hand over to you and you shall drive them out before you.
23.32: You shall not make a covenant with them or their gods.
23.33: They must not live in your land. For if you serve their gods, this will become a snare to you.

24.1: Chapter 24 - Ratification of the Covenant. Moses himself was told: Come up to the LORD, you and Aaron, with Nadab, Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel. You shall bow down at a distance.
24.2: Moses alone is to come close to the LORD; the others shall not come close, and the people shall not come up with them.
24.3: When Moses came to the people and related all the words and ordinances of the LORD, they all answered with one voice, “We will do everything that the LORD has told us.”
24.4: Moses then wrote down all the words of the LORD and, rising early in the morning, he built at the foot of the mountain an altar and twelve sacred stones for the twelve tribes of Israel.
24.5: Then, having sent young men of the Israelites to offer burnt offerings and sacrifice young bulls as communion offerings to the LORD,
24.6: Moses took half of the blood and put it in large bowls; the other half he splashed on the altar.
24.7: Taking the book of the covenant, he read it aloud to the people, who answered, “All that the LORD has said, we will hear and do.”
24.8: Then he took the blood and splashed it on the people, saying, “This is the blood of the covenant which the LORD has made with you according to all these words.”
24.9: Moses then went up with Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and seventy elders of Israel,
24.10: and they beheld the God of Israel. Under his feet there appeared to be sapphire tilework, as clear as the sky itself.
24.11: Yet he did not lay a hand on these chosen Israelites. They saw God, and they ate and drank.
24.12: Moses on the Mountain. The LORD said to Moses: Come up to me on the mountain and, while you are there, I will give you the stone tablets on which I have written the commandments intended for their instruction.
24.13: So Moses set out with Joshua, his assistant, and went up to the mountain of God.
24.14: He told the elders, “Wait here for us until we return to you. Aaron and Hur are with you. Anyone with a complaint should approach them.”
24.15: Moses went up the mountain. Then the cloud covered the mountain.
24.16: The glory of the LORD settled upon Mount Sinai. The cloud covered it for six days, and on the seventh day he called to Moses from the midst of the cloud.
24.17: To the Israelites the glory of the LORD was seen as a consuming fire on the top of the mountain.
24.18: But Moses entered into the midst of the cloud and went up on the mountain. He was on the mountain for forty days and forty nights.

25.1: Chapter 25 - Collection of Materials. The LORD spoke to Moses:
25.2: Speak to the Israelites: Let them receive contributions for me. From each you shall receive the contribution that their hearts prompt them to give me.
25.3: These are the contributions you shall accept from them: gold, silver, and bronze;
25.4: violet, purple, and scarlet yarn; fine linen and goat hair;
25.5: rams’ skins dyed red, and tahash skins; acacia wood;
25.6: oil for the light; spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense;
25.7: onyx stones and other gems for mounting on the ephod and the breastpiece.
25.8: They are to make a sanctuary for me, that I may dwell in their midst.
25.9: According to all that I show you regarding the pattern of the tabernacle and the pattern of its furnishings, so you are to make it.
25.10: Plan of the Ark. You shall make an ark of acacia wood, two and a half cubits long, one and a half cubits wide, and one and a half cubits high.
25.11: Plate it inside and outside with pure gold, and put a molding of gold around the top of it.
25.12: Cast four gold rings and put them on the four supports of the ark, two rings on one side and two on the opposite side.
25.13: Then make poles of acacia wood and plate them with gold.
25.14: These poles you are to put through the rings on the sides of the ark, for carrying it;
25.15: they must remain in the rings of the ark and never be withdrawn.
25.16: In the ark you are to put the covenant which I will give you.
25.17: You shall then make a cover of pure gold, two and a half cubits long, and one and a half cubits wide.
25.18: Make two cherubim of beaten gold for the two ends of the cover;
25.19: make one cherub at one end, and the other at the other end, of one piece with the cover, at each end.
25.20: The cherubim shall have their wings spread out above, sheltering the cover with them; they shall face each other, with their faces looking toward the cover.
25.21: This cover you shall then place on top of the ark. In the ark itself you are to put the covenant which I will give you.
25.22: There I will meet you and there, from above the cover, between the two cherubim on the ark of the covenant, I will tell you all that I command you regarding the Israelites.
25.23: The Table. You shall also make a table of acacia wood, two cubits long, a cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high.
25.24: Plate it with pure gold and make a molding of gold around it.
25.25: Make a frame for it, a handbreadth high, and make a molding of gold around the frame.
25.26: You shall also make four rings of gold for it and fasten them at the four corners, one at each leg.
25.27: The rings shall be alongside the frame as holders for the poles to carry the table.
25.28: These poles for carrying the table you shall make of acacia wood and plate with gold.
25.29: You shall make its plates and cups, as well as its pitchers and bowls for pouring libations; make them of pure gold.
25.30: On the table you shall always keep showbread set before me.
25.31: The Menorah. You shall make a menorah of pure beaten gold—its shaft and branches—with its cups and knobs and petals springing directly from it.
25.32: Six branches are to extend from its sides, three branches on one side, and three on the other.
25.33: On one branch there are to be three cups, shaped like almond blossoms, each with its knob and petals; on the opposite branch there are to be three cups, shaped like almond blossoms, each with its knob and petals; and so for the six branches that extend from the menorah.
25.34: On the menorah there are to be four cups, shaped like almond blossoms, with their knobs and petals.
25.35: The six branches that go out from the menorah are to have a knob under each pair.
25.36: Their knobs and branches shall so spring from it that the whole will form a single piece of pure beaten gold.
25.37: You shall then make seven lamps for it and so set up the lamps that they give their light on the space in front of the menorah.
25.38: These, as well as the trimming shears and trays, must be of pure gold.
25.39: Use a talent of pure gold for the menorah and all these utensils.
25.40: See that you make them according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.

26.1: Chapter 26 - The Tent Cloth. The tabernacle itself you shall make out of ten sheets woven of fine linen twined and of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn, with cherubim embroidered on them.
26.2: The length of each shall be twenty-eight cubits, and the width four cubits; all the sheets shall be of the same size.
26.3: Five of the sheets are to be joined one to another; and the same for the other five.
26.4: Make loops of violet yarn along the edge of the end sheet in one set, and the same along the edge of the end sheet in the other set.
26.5: Make fifty loops along the edge of the end sheet in the first set, and fifty loops along the edge of the corresponding sheet in the second set, and so placed that the loops are directly opposite each other.
26.6: Then make fifty clasps of gold and join the two sets of sheets, so that the tabernacle forms one whole.
26.7: Also make sheets woven of goat hair for a tent over the tabernacle. Make eleven such sheets;
26.8: the length of each shall be thirty cubits, and the width four cubits: all eleven sheets shall be of the same size.
26.9: Join five of the sheets into one set, and the other six sheets into another set. Use the sixth sheet double at the front of the tent.
26.10: Make fifty loops along the edge of the end sheet in one set, and fifty loops along the edge of the end sheet in the second set.
26.11: Also make fifty bronze clasps and put them into the loops, to join the tent into one whole.
26.12: There will be an extra half sheet of tent covering, which shall be allowed to hang down over the rear of the tabernacle.
26.13: Likewise, the sheets of the tent will have an extra cubit’s length to be left hanging down on either side of the tabernacle to cover it.
26.14: Over the tent itself make a covering of rams’ skins dyed red, and above that, a covering of tahash skins.
26.15: The Framework. You shall make frames for the tabernacle, acacia-wood uprights.
26.16: The length of each frame is to be ten cubits, and its width one and a half cubits.
26.17: Each frame shall have two arms joined one to another; so you are to make all the frames of the tabernacle.
26.18: Make the frames of the tabernacle as follows: twenty frames on the south side,
26.19: with forty silver pedestals under the twenty frames, two pedestals under each frame for its two arms;
26.20: twenty frames on the other side of the tabernacle, the north side,
26.21: with their forty silver pedestals, two pedestals under each frame.
26.22: At the rear of the tabernacle, to the west, six frames,
26.23: and two frames for the corners of the tabernacle, at its rear.
26.24: These two shall be double at the bottom, and likewise double at the top, to the first ring. That is how both corner frames are to be made.
26.25: Thus, there shall be eight frames, with their sixteen silver pedestals, two pedestals under each frame.
26.26: Also make bars of acacia wood: five for the frames on one side of the tabernacle,
26.27: five for those on the other side, and five for those at the rear, to the west.
26.28: The center bar, at the middle of the frames, shall reach across from end to end.
26.29: Plate the frames with gold, and make gold rings on them as holders for the bars, which are also to be plated with gold.
26.30: You shall set up the tabernacle according to its plan, which you were shown on the mountain.
26.31: The Veils. You shall make a veil woven of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn, and of fine linen twined, with cherubim embroidered on it.
26.32: It is to be hung on four gold-plated columns of acacia wood, which shall have gold hooks and shall rest on four silver pedestals.
26.33: Hang the veil from clasps. The ark of the covenant you shall bring inside, behind this veil which divides the holy place from the holy of holies.
26.34: Set the cover on the ark of the covenant in the holy of holies.
26.35: Outside the veil you shall place the table and the menorah, the latter on the south side of the tabernacle, opposite the table, which is to be put on the north side.
26.36: For the entrance of the tent make a variegated curtain of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and of fine linen twined.
26.37: Make five columns of acacia wood for this curtain; plate them with gold, with their hooks of gold; and cast five bronze pedestals for them.

27.1: Chapter 27 - The Altar for Burnt Offerings. You shall make an altar of acacia wood, on a square, five cubits long and five cubits wide; it shall be three cubits high.
27.2: At the four corners make horns that are of one piece with the altar. You shall then plate it with bronze.
27.3: Make pots for removing the ashes, as well as shovels, basins, forks, and fire pans; all these utensils you shall make of bronze.
27.4: Make for it a grating, a bronze network; make four bronze rings for it, one at each of its four corners.
27.5: Put it down around the altar, on the ground. This network is to be half as high as the altar.
27.6: You shall also make poles of acacia wood for the altar, and plate them with bronze.
27.7: These poles are to be put through the rings, so that they are on either side of the altar when it is carried.
27.8: Make the altar itself in the form of a hollow box. Just as it was shown you on the mountain, so it is to be made.
27.9: Court of the Tabernacle. You shall also make a court for the tabernacle. On the south side the court shall have hangings, of fine linen twined, a hundred cubits long,
27.10: with twenty columns and twenty pedestals of bronze; the hooks and bands on the columns shall be of silver.
27.11: On the north side there shall be similar hangings, a hundred cubits long, with twenty columns and twenty pedestals of bronze; the hooks and bands on the columns shall be of silver.
27.12: On the west side, across the width of the court, there shall be hangings, fifty cubits long, with ten columns and ten pedestals.
27.13: The width of the court on the east side shall be fifty cubits.
27.14: On one side there shall be hangings to the extent of fifteen cubits, with three columns and three pedestals;
27.15: on the other side there shall be hangings to the extent of fifteen cubits, with three columns and three pedestals.
27.16: At the gate of the court there shall be a variegated curtain, twenty cubits long, woven of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and of fine linen twined. It shall have four columns and four pedestals.
27.17: All the columns around the court shall have bands and hooks of silver, and pedestals of bronze.
27.18: The court is to be one hundred cubits long, fifty cubits wide, and five cubits high. Fine linen twined must be used, and the pedestals must be of bronze.
27.19: All the fittings of the tabernacle, whatever be their use, as well as all its tent pegs and all the tent pegs of the court, must be of bronze.
27.20: Oil for the Lamps. You shall command the Israelites to bring you clear oil of crushed olives, to be used for the light, so that you may keep lamps burning always.
27.21: From evening to morning Aaron and his sons shall maintain them before the LORD in the tent of meeting, outside the veil which hangs in front of the covenant. This shall be a perpetual statute for the Israelites throughout their generations.

28.1: Chapter 28 - The Priestly Vestments. Have your brother Aaron, and with him his sons, brought to you, from among the Israelites, that they may be my priests: Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar, Aaron’s sons.
28.2: For the glorious adornment of your brother Aaron you shall have sacred vestments made.
28.3: Therefore, tell the various artisans whom I have endowed with skill to make vestments for Aaron to consecrate him as my priest.
28.4: These are the vestments they shall make: a breastpiece, an ephod, a robe, a brocade tunic, a turban, and a sash. In making these sacred vestments which your brother Aaron and his sons are to wear in serving as my priests,
28.5: they shall use gold, violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and fine linen.
28.6: The Ephod and Breastpiece. The ephod they shall make of gold thread and of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn, embroidered on cloth of fine linen twined.
28.7: It shall have a pair of shoulder straps joined to its two upper ends.
28.8: The embroidered belt of the ephod shall extend out from it and, like it, be made of gold thread, of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn, and of fine linen twined.
28.9: Get two onyx stones and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel:
28.10: six of their names on one stone, and the names of the remaining six on the other stone, in the order of their birth.
28.11: As a gem-cutter engraves a seal, so shall you have the two stones engraved with the names of the sons of Israel and then mounted in gold filigree work.
28.12: Set these two stones on the shoulder straps of the ephod as memorial stones of the sons of Israel. Thus Aaron shall bear their names on his shoulders as a reminder before the LORD.
28.14: as well as two chains of pure gold, twisted like cords, and fasten the cordlike chains to the filigree rosettes.
28.15: The breastpiece of decision you shall also have made, embroidered like the ephod with gold thread and violet, purple, and scarlet yarn on cloth of fine linen twined.
28.16: It is to be square when folded double, a span high and a span wide.
28.17: On it you shall mount four rows of precious stones: in the first row, a carnelian, a topaz, and an emerald;
28.18: in the second row, a garnet, a sapphire, and a beryl;
28.19: in the third row, a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst;
28.20: in the fourth row, a chrysolite, an onyx, and a jasper. These stones are to be mounted in gold filigree work,
28.21: twelve of them to match the names of the sons of Israel, each stone engraved like a seal with the name of one of the twelve tribes.
28.22: When the chains of pure gold, twisted like cords, have been made for the breastpiece,
28.23: you shall then make two rings of gold for it and fasten them to the two upper ends of the breastpiece.
28.24: The gold cords are then to be fastened to the two rings at the upper ends of the breastpiece,
28.25: the other two ends of the cords being fastened in front to the two filigree rosettes which are attached to the shoulder straps of the ephod.
28.26: Make two other rings of gold and put them on the two lower ends of the breastpiece, on its edge that faces the ephod.
28.27: Then make two more rings of gold and fasten them to the bottom of the shoulder straps next to where they join the ephod in front, just above its embroidered belt.
28.28: Violet ribbons shall bind the rings of the breastpiece to the rings of the ephod, so that the breastpiece will stay right above the embroidered belt of the ephod and not swing loose from it.
28.29: Whenever Aaron enters the sanctuary, he will thus bear the names of the sons of Israel on the breastpiece of decision over his heart as a constant reminder before the LORD.
28.30: In this breastpiece of decision you shall put the Urim and Thummim, that they may be over Aaron’s heart whenever he enters the presence of the LORD. Thus he shall always bear the decisions for the Israelites over his heart in the presence of the LORD.
28.31: Other Vestments. The robe of the ephod you shall make entirely of violet material.
28.32: It shall have an opening for the head in the center, and around this opening there shall be a selvage, woven as at the opening of a shirt, to keep it from being torn.
28.33: At the hem at the bottom you shall make pomegranates, woven of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and fine linen twined, with gold bells between them;
28.34: a gold bell, a pomegranate, a gold bell, a pomegranate, all around the hem of the robe.
28.35: Aaron shall wear it when ministering, that its sound may be heard as he enters and leaves the LORD’s presence in the sanctuary; else he will die.
28.36: You shall also make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it, as on a seal engraving, “Sacred to the LORD.”
28.37: This plate is to be tied over the turban with a violet ribbon in such a way that it rests on the front of the turban,
28.38: over Aaron’s forehead. Since Aaron bears whatever guilt the Israelites may incur in consecrating any of their sacred gifts, this plate must always be over his forehead, so that they may find favor with the LORD.
28.39: The tunic of fine linen shall be brocaded. The turban shall be made of fine linen. The sash shall be of variegated work.
28.40: Likewise, for the glorious adornment of Aaron’s sons you shall have tunics and sashes and skullcaps made, for glorious splendor.
28.41: With these you shall clothe your brother Aaron and his sons. Anoint and install them, consecrating them as my priests.
28.42: You must also make linen pants for them, to cover their naked flesh from their loins to their thighs.
28.43: Aaron and his sons shall wear them whenever they go into the tent of meeting or approach the altar to minister in the sanctuary, lest they incur guilt and die. This shall be a perpetual ordinance for him and for his descendants.

29.1: Chapter 29 - Consecration of the Priests. This is the rite you shall perform in consecrating them as my priests. Procure a young bull and two unblemished rams.
29.2: With bran flour make unleavened cakes mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil,
29.3: and put them in a basket. Take the basket of them along with the bull and the two rams.
29.4: Aaron and his sons you shall also bring to the entrance of the tent of meeting, and there wash them with water.
29.5: Take the vestments and clothe Aaron with the tunic, the robe of the ephod, the ephod itself, and the breastpiece, fastening the embroidered belt of the ephod around him.
29.6: Put the turban on his head, the sacred diadem on the turban.
29.7: Then take the anointing oil and pour it on his head, and anoint him.
29.8: Bring forward his sons also and clothe them with the tunics,
29.9: gird them with the sashes, and tie the skullcaps on them. Thus shall the priesthood be theirs by a perpetual statute, and thus shall you install Aaron and his sons.
29.10: Installation Sacrifices. Now bring forward the bull in front of the tent of meeting. There Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.
29.11: Then slaughter the bull before the LORD, at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
29.12: Take some of its blood and with your finger put it on the horns of the altar. All the rest of the blood you shall pour out at the base of the altar.
29.13: All the fat that covers its inner organs, as well as the lobe of its liver and its two kidneys, together with the fat that is on them, you shall take and burn on the altar.
29.14: But the meat and hide and dung of the bull you must burn up outside the camp, since this is a purification offering.
29.15: Then take one of the rams, and after Aaron and his sons have laid their hands on its head,
29.16: slaughter it. The blood you shall take and splash on all the sides of the altar.
29.17: Cut the ram into pieces; you shall wash its inner organs and shanks and put them with the pieces and with the head.
29.18: Then you shall burn the entire ram on the altar, since it is a burnt offering, a sweet-smelling oblation to the LORD.
29.19: After this take the other ram, and when Aaron and his sons have laid their hands on its head,
29.20: slaughter it. Some of its blood you shall take and put on the tip of Aaron’s right ear and on the tips of his sons’ right ears and on the thumbs of their right hands and the great toes of their right feet. Splash the rest of the blood on all the sides of the altar.
29.21: Then take some of the blood that is on the altar, together with some of the anointing oil, and sprinkle this on Aaron and his vestments, as well as on his sons and their vestments, that he and his sons and their vestments may be sacred.
29.22: Now, from this ram you shall take its fat: its fatty tail, the fat that covers its inner organs, the lobe of its liver, its two kidneys with the fat that is on them, and its right thigh, since this is the ram for installation;
29.23: then, out of the basket of unleavened food that you have set before the LORD, you shall take one of the loaves of bread, one of the cakes made with oil, and one of the wafers.
29.24: All these things you shall put into the hands of Aaron and his sons, so that they may raise them as an elevated offering before the LORD.
29.25: After you receive them back from their hands, you shall burn them on top of the burnt offering on the altar as a sweet-smelling oblation to the LORD.
29.26: Finally, take the brisket of Aaron’s installation ram and raise it as an elevated offering before the LORD; this is to be your own portion.
29.27: Thus shall you set aside the brisket of whatever elevated offering is raised, as well as the thigh of whatever contribution is raised up, whether this be the installation ram or anything else belonging to Aaron or to his sons.
29.28: Such things are due to Aaron and his sons from the Israelites by a perpetual statute as a contribution. From their communion offerings, too, the Israelites shall make a contribution, their contribution to the LORD.
29.29: The sacred vestments of Aaron shall be passed down to his sons after him, that in them they may be anointed and installed.
29.30: The son who succeeds him as priest and who is to enter the tent of meeting to minister in the sanctuary shall be clothed with them for seven days.
29.31: You shall take the installation ram and boil its meat in a holy place.
29.32: At the entrance of the tent of meeting Aaron and his sons shall eat the meat of the ram and the bread that is in the basket.
29.33: They themselves are to eat of these things by which atonement was made at their installation and consecration; but no unauthorized person may eat of them, since they are sacred.
29.34: If some of the meat of the installation sacrifice or some of the bread remains over on the next day, this remnant you must burn up; it is not to be eaten, since it is sacred.
29.35: Carry out all these commands in regard to Aaron and his sons just as I have given them to you. Seven days you shall spend installing them,
29.36: sacrificing a bull each day as a purification offering, to make atonement. Thus you shall purify the altar by purging it, and you shall anoint it in order to consecrate it.
29.37: Seven days you shall spend in purging the altar and in consecrating it. Then the altar will be most sacred, and whatever touches it will become sacred.
29.38: Now, this is what you shall regularly offer on the altar: two yearling lambs as the sacrifice established for each day;
29.39: one lamb in the morning and the other lamb at the evening twilight.
29.40: With the first lamb there shall be a tenth of an ephah of bran flour mixed with a fourth of a hin of oil of crushed olives and, as its libation, a fourth of a hin of wine.
29.41: The other lamb you shall offer at the evening twilight, with the same grain offering and libation as in the morning. You shall offer this as a sweet-smelling oblation to the LORD.
29.42: Throughout your generations this regular burnt offering shall be made before the LORD at the entrance of the tent of meeting, where I will meet you and speak to you.
29.43: There, at the altar, I will meet the Israelites; hence, it will be made sacred by my glory.
29.44: Thus I will consecrate the tent of meeting and the altar, just as I also consecrate Aaron and his sons to be my priests.
29.45: I will dwell in the midst of the Israelites and will be their God.
29.46: They shall know that I, the LORD, am their God who brought them out of the land of Egypt, so that I, the LORD, their God, might dwell among them.

30.1: Chapter 30 - Altar of Incense. For burning incense you shall make an altar of acacia wood,
30.2: with a square surface, a cubit long, a cubit wide, and two cubits high, with horns that are of one piece with it.
30.3: Its grate on top, its walls on all four sides, and its horns you shall plate with pure gold. Put a gold molding around it.
30.4: Underneath the molding you shall put gold rings, two on one side and two on the opposite side, as holders for the poles used in carrying it.
30.5: Make the poles, too, of acacia wood and plate them with gold.
30.6: This altar you are to place in front of the veil that hangs before the ark of the covenant where I will meet you.
30.7: On it Aaron shall burn fragrant incense. Morning after morning, when he prepares the lamps,
30.8: and again in the evening twilight, when he lights the lamps, he shall burn incense. Throughout your generations this shall be the regular incense offering before the LORD.
30.9: On this altar you shall not offer up any profane incense, or any burnt offering or grain offering; nor shall you pour out a libation upon it.
30.10: Once a year Aaron shall purge its horns. Throughout your generations he is to purge it once a year with the blood of the atoning purification offering. This altar is most sacred to the LORD.
30.11: Census Tax. The LORD also told Moses:
30.12: When you take a census of the Israelites who are to be enrolled, each one, as he is enrolled, shall give the LORD a ransom for his life, so that no plague may come upon them for being enrolled.
30.13: This is what everyone who is enrolled must pay: a half-shekel, according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel—twenty gerahs to the shekel—a half-shekel contribution to the LORD.
30.14: Everyone who is enrolled, of twenty years or more, must give the contribution to the LORD.
30.15: The rich need not give more, nor shall the poor give less, than a half-shekel in this contribution to the LORD to pay the ransom for their lives.
30.16: When you receive this ransom money from the Israelites, you shall donate it to the service of the tent of meeting, that there it may be a reminder of the Israelites before the LORD of the ransom paid for their lives.
30.17: The Basin. The LORD told Moses:
30.18: For ablutions you shall make a bronze basin with a bronze stand. Place it between the tent of meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
30.19: Aaron and his sons shall use it in washing their hands and feet.
30.20: When they are about to enter the tent of meeting, they must wash with water, lest they die. Likewise when they approach the altar to minister, to offer an oblation to the LORD,
30.21: they must wash their hands and feet, lest they die. This shall be a perpetual statute for him and his descendants throughout their generations.
30.22: The Anointing Oil. The LORD told Moses:
30.23: Take the finest spices: five hundred shekels of free-flowing myrrh; half that amount, that is, two hundred and fifty shekels, of fragrant cinnamon; two hundred and fifty shekels of fragrant cane;
30.24: five hundred shekels of cassia—all according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel; together with a hin of olive oil;
30.25: and blend them into sacred anointing oil, perfumed ointment expertly prepared. With this sacred anointing oil
30.26: you shall anoint the tent of meeting and the ark of the covenant,
30.27: the table and all its utensils, the menorah and its utensils, the altar of incense
30.28: and the altar for burnt offerings with all its utensils, and the basin with its stand.
30.29: When you have consecrated them, they shall be most sacred; whatever touches them shall be sacred.
30.30: Aaron and his sons you shall also anoint and consecrate as my priests.
30.31: Tell the Israelites: As sacred anointing oil this shall belong to me throughout your generations.
30.32: It may not be used in any ordinary anointing of the body, nor may you make any other oil of a like mixture. It is sacred, and shall be treated as sacred by you.
30.33: Whoever prepares a perfume like this, or whoever puts any of this on an unauthorized person, shall be cut off from his people.
30.34: The Incense. The LORD told Moses: Take these aromatic substances: storax and onycha and galbanum, these and pure frankincense in equal parts;
30.35: and blend them into incense. This fragrant powder, expertly prepared, is to be salted and so kept pure and sacred.
30.36: Grind some of it into fine dust and put this before the covenant in the tent of meeting where I will meet you. This incense shall be treated as most sacred by you.
30.37: You may not make incense of a like mixture for yourselves; you must treat it as sacred to the LORD.
30.38: Whoever makes an incense like this for his own enjoyment of its fragrance, shall be cut off from his people.

31.1: Chapter 31 - Choice of Artisans. The LORD said to Moses:
31.2: See, I have singled out Bezalel, son of Uri, son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah,
31.3: and I have filled him with a divine spirit of skill and understanding and knowledge in every craft:
31.4: in the production of embroidery, in making things of gold, silver, or bronze,
31.5: in cutting and mounting precious stones, in carving wood, and in every other craft.
31.6: As his assistant I myself have appointed Oholiab, son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan. I have also endowed all the experts with the necessary skill to make all the things I have commanded you:
31.7: the tent of meeting, the ark of the covenant with its cover, all the furnishings of the tent,
31.8: the table with its utensils, the pure gold menorah with all its utensils, the altar of incense,
31.9: the altar for burnt offerings with all its utensils, the basin with its stand,
31.10: the service cloths, the sacred vestments for Aaron the priest, the vestments for his sons in their ministry,
31.11: the anointing oil, and the fragrant incense for the sanctuary. According to all I have commanded you, so shall they do.
31.12: Sabbath Laws. The LORD said to Moses:
31.13: You must also tell the Israelites: Keep my sabbaths, for that is to be the sign between you and me throughout the generations, to show that it is I, the LORD, who make you holy.
31.14: Therefore, you must keep the sabbath for it is holiness for you. Whoever desecrates it shall be put to death. If anyone does work on that day, that person must be cut off from the people.
31.15: Six days there are for doing work, but the seventh day is the sabbath of complete rest, holy to the LORD. Anyone who does work on the sabbath day shall be put to death.
31.16: So shall the Israelites observe the sabbath, keeping it throughout their generations as an everlasting covenant.
31.17: Between me and the Israelites it is to be an everlasting sign; for in six days the LORD made the heavens and the earth, but on the seventh day he rested at his ease.
31.18: When the LORD had finished speaking to Moses on Mount Sinai, he gave him the two tablets of the covenant, the stone tablets inscribed by God’s own finger.

32.1: VII. Israel’s Apostasy and God’s Renewal of the Covenant Chapter 32 - The Golden Calf. When the people saw that Moses was delayed in coming down from the mountain, they gathered around Aaron and said to him, “Come, make us a god who will go before us; as for that man Moses who brought us out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him.”
32.2: Aaron replied, “Take off the golden earrings that your wives, your sons, and your daughters are wearing, and bring them to me.”
32.3: So all the people took off their earrings and brought them to Aaron.
32.4: He received their offering, and fashioning it with a tool, made a molten calf. Then they cried out, “These are your gods, Israel, who brought you up from the land of Egypt.”
32.5: On seeing this, Aaron built an altar in front of the calf and proclaimed, “Tomorrow is a feast of the LORD.”
32.6: Early the next day the people sacrificed burnt offerings and brought communion sacrifices. Then they sat down to eat and drink, and rose up to revel.
32.7: Then the LORD said to Moses: Go down at once because your people, whom you brought out of the land of Egypt, have acted corruptly.
32.8: They have quickly turned aside from the way I commanded them, making for themselves a molten calf and bowing down to it, sacrificing to it and crying out, “These are your gods, Israel, who brought you up from the land of Egypt!”
32.9: I have seen this people, how stiff-necked they are, continued the LORD to Moses.
32.10: Let me alone, then, that my anger may burn against them to consume them. Then I will make of you a great nation.
32.11: But Moses implored the LORD, his God, saying, “Why, O LORD, should your anger burn against your people, whom you brought out of the land of Egypt with great power and with a strong hand?
32.12: Why should the Egyptians say, ‘With evil intent he brought them out, that he might kill them in the mountains and wipe them off the face of the earth’? Turn from your burning wrath; change your mind about punishing your people.
32.13: Remember your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, and how you swore to them by your own self, saying, ‘I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky; and all this land that I promised, I will give your descendants as their perpetual heritage.’”
32.14: So the LORD changed his mind about the punishment he had threatened to inflict on his people.
32.15: Moses then turned and came down the mountain with the two tablets of the covenant in his hands, tablets that were written on both sides, front and back.
32.16: The tablets were made by God; the writing was the writing of God, engraved on the tablets.
32.17: Now, when Joshua heard the noise of the people shouting, he said to Moses, “That sounds like a battle in the camp.”
32.18: But Moses answered, “It is not the noise of victory, it is not the noise of defeat; the sound I hear is singing.”
32.19: As he drew near the camp, he saw the calf and the dancing. Then Moses’ anger burned, and he threw the tablets down and broke them on the base of the mountain.
32.20: Taking the calf they had made, he burned it in the fire and then ground it down to powder, which he scattered on the water and made the Israelites drink.
32.21: Moses asked Aaron, “What did this people do to you that you should lead them into a grave sin?”
32.22: Aaron replied, “Do not let my lord be angry. You know how the people are prone to evil.
32.23: They said to me, ‘Make us a god to go before us; as for this man Moses who brought us out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him.’
32.24: So I told them, ‘Whoever is wearing gold, take it off.’ They gave it to me, and I threw it into the fire, and this calf came out.”
32.25: Moses saw that the people were running wild because Aaron had lost control—to the secret delight of their foes.
32.26: Moses stood at the gate of the camp and shouted, “Whoever is for the LORD, come to me!” All the Levites then rallied to him,
32.27: and he told them, “Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: Each of you put your sword on your hip! Go back and forth through the camp, from gate to gate, and kill your brothers, your friends, your neighbors!”
32.28: The Levites did as Moses had commanded, and that day about three thousand of the people fell.
32.29: Then Moses said, “Today you are installed as priests for the LORD, for you went against your own sons and brothers, to bring a blessing upon yourselves this day.”
32.30: The Atonement. On the next day Moses said to the people, “You have committed a grave sin. Now I will go up to the LORD; perhaps I may be able to make atonement for your sin.”
32.31: So Moses returned to the LORD and said, “Ah, this people has committed a grave sin in making a god of gold for themselves!
32.32: Now if you would only forgive their sin! But if you will not, then blot me out of the book that you have written.”
32.33: The LORD answered Moses: Only the one who has sinned against me will I blot out of my book.
32.34: Now, go and lead the people where I have told you. See, my angel will go before you. When it is time for me to punish, I will punish them for their sin.
32.35: Thus the LORD struck the people for making the calf, the one that Aaron made.

33.1: Chapter 33 - The LORD spoke to Moses: Go! You and the people whom you have brought up from the land of Egypt are to go up from here to the land about which I swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob: I will give it to your descendants.
33.2: Driving out the Canaanites, Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites, I will send an angel before you
33.3: to a land flowing with milk and honey. But I myself will not go up in your company, because you are a stiff-necked people; otherwise I might consume you on the way.
33.4: When the people heard this painful news, they mourned, and no one wore any ornaments.
33.5: The LORD spoke to Moses: Speak to the Israelites: You are a stiff-necked people. Were I to go up in your company even for a moment, I would destroy you. Now off with your ornaments! Let me think what to do with you.
33.6: So, from Mount Horeb onward, the Israelites stripped off their ornaments.
33.7: Moses’ Intimacy with God. Moses used to pitch a tent outside the camp at some distance. It was called the tent of meeting. Anyone who wished to consult the LORD would go to the tent of meeting outside the camp.
33.8: Whenever Moses went out to the tent, the people would all rise and stand at the entrance of their own tents, watching Moses until he entered the tent.
33.9: As Moses entered the tent, the column of cloud would come down and stand at its entrance while the LORD spoke with Moses.
33.10: On seeing the column of cloud stand at the entrance of the tent, all the people would rise and bow down at the entrance of their own tents.
33.11: The LORD used to speak to Moses face to face, as a person speaks to a friend. Moses would then return to the camp, but his young assistant, Joshua, son of Nun, never left the tent.
33.12: Moses said to the LORD, “See, you are telling me: Lead this people. But you have not let me know whom you will send with me. Yet you have said: You are my intimate friend; You have found favor with me.
33.13: Now, if I have found favor with you, please let me know your ways so that, in knowing you, I may continue to find favor with you. See, this nation is indeed your own people.
33.14: The LORD answered: I myself will go along, to give you rest.
33.15: Moses replied, “If you are not going yourself, do not make us go up from here.
33.16: For how can it be known that I and your people have found favor with you, except by your going with us? Then we, your people and I, will be singled out from every other people on the surface of the earth.”
33.17: The LORD said to Moses: This request, too, which you have made, I will carry out, because you have found favor with me and you are my intimate friend.
33.18: Then Moses said, “Please let me see your glory!”
33.19: The LORD answered: I will make all my goodness pass before you, and I will proclaim my name, “LORD,” before you; I who show favor to whom I will, I who grant mercy to whom I will.
33.20: But you cannot see my face, for no one can see me and live.
33.21: Here, continued the LORD, is a place near me where you shall station yourself on the rock.
33.22: When my glory passes I will set you in the cleft of the rock and will cover you with my hand until I have passed by.
33.23: Then I will remove my hand, so that you may see my back; but my face may not be seen.

34.1: Chapter 34 - Renewal of the Tablets. The LORD said to Moses: “Cut two stone tablets like the former, that I may write on them the words which were on the former tablets that you broke.
34.2: Get ready for tomorrow morning, when you are to go up Mount Sinai and there present yourself to me on the top of the mountain.
34.3: No one shall come up with you, and let no one even be seen on any part of the mountain; even the sheep and the cattle are not to graze in front of this mountain.”
34.4: Moses then cut two stone tablets like the former, and early the next morning he went up Mount Sinai as the LORD had commanded him, taking in his hand the two stone tablets.
34.5: The LORD came down in a cloud and stood with him there and proclaimed the name, “LORD.”
34.6: So the LORD passed before him and proclaimed: The LORD, the LORD, a God gracious and merciful, slow to anger and abounding in love and fidelity,
34.7: continuing his love for a thousand generations, and forgiving wickedness, rebellion, and sin; yet not declaring the guilty guiltless, but bringing punishment for their parents’ wickedness on children and children’s children to the third and fourth generation!
34.8: Moses at once knelt and bowed down to the ground.
34.9: Then he said, “If I find favor with you, Lord, please, Lord, come along in our company. This is indeed a stiff-necked people; yet pardon our wickedness and sins, and claim us as your own.”
34.10: Religious Laws. The LORD said: Here is the covenant I will make. Before all your people I will perform marvels never before done in any nation anywhere on earth, so that all the people among whom you live may see the work of the LORD. Awe-inspiring are the deeds I will perform with you!
34.11: As for you, observe what I am commanding you today. See, I am about to drive out before you the Amorites, Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites.
34.12: Take care not to make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land that you are to enter; lest they become a snare among you.
34.13: Tear down their altars; smash their sacred stones, and cut down their asherahs.
34.14: You shall not bow down to any other god, for the LORD—“Jealous” his name—is a jealous God.
34.15: Do not make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land; else, when they prostitute themselves with their gods and sacrifice to them, one of them may invite you and you may partake of the sacrifice.
34.16: And when you take their daughters as wives for your sons, and their daughters prostitute themselves with their gods, they will make your sons do the same.
34.17: You shall not make for yourselves molten gods.
34.18: You shall keep the festival of Unleavened Bread. For seven days at the appointed time in the month of Abib you are to eat unleavened bread, as I commanded you; for in the month of Abib you came out of Egypt.
34.19: To me belongs every male that opens the womb among all your livestock, whether in the herd or in the flock.
34.20: The firstling of a donkey you shall redeem with a lamb; if you do not redeem it, you must break its neck. The firstborn among your sons you shall redeem. No one shall appear before me empty-handed.
34.21: Six days you may labor, but on the seventh day you shall rest; even during the seasons of plowing and harvesting you must rest.
34.22: You shall keep the feast of Weeks with the first fruits of the wheat harvest, likewise, the feast of the Ingathering at the close of the year.
34.23: Three times a year all your men shall appear before the Lord, the LORD God of Israel.
34.24: Since I will drive out the nations before you and enlarge your territory, no one will covet your land when you go up three times a year to appear before the LORD, your God.
34.25: You shall not offer me the blood of sacrifice with anything leavened, nor shall the sacrifice of the Passover feast be kept overnight for the next day.
34.26: The choicest first fruits of your soil you shall bring to the house of the LORD, your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.
34.27: Radiance of Moses’ Face. Then the LORD said to Moses: Write down these words, for in accordance with these words I have made a covenant with you and with Israel.
34.28: So Moses was there with the LORD for forty days and forty nights, without eating any food or drinking any water, and he wrote on the tablets the words of the covenant, the ten words.
34.29: As Moses came down from Mount Sinai with the two tablets of the covenant in his hands, he did not know that the skin of his face had become radiant while he spoke with the LORD.
34.30: When Aaron, then, and the other Israelites saw Moses and noticed how radiant the skin of his face had become, they were afraid to come near him.
34.31: Only after Moses called to them did Aaron and all the leaders of the community come back to him. Moses then spoke to them.
34.32: Later, all the Israelites came up to him, and he enjoined on them all that the LORD had told him on Mount Sinai.
34.33: When Moses finished speaking with them, he put a veil over his face.
34.34: Whenever Moses entered the presence of the LORD to speak with him, he removed the veil until he came out again. On coming out, he would tell the Israelites all that he had been commanded.
34.35: Then the Israelites would see that the skin of Moses’ face was radiant; so he would again put the veil over his face until he went in to speak with the LORD.

35.1: VIII. The Building of the Tabernacle and the Descent of God’s Glory Upon It Chapter 35 - Sabbath Regulations. Moses assembled the whole Israelite community and said to them, “These are the words the LORD has commanded to be observed.
35.2: On six days work may be done, but the seventh day shall be holy to you as the sabbath of complete rest to the LORD. Anyone who does work on that day shall be put to death.
35.3: You shall not even light a fire in any of your dwellings on the sabbath day.”
35.4: Collection of Materials. Moses said to the whole Israelite community, “This is what the LORD has commanded:
35.5: Receive from among you contributions for the LORD. Everyone, as his heart prompts him, shall bring, as a contribution to the LORD, gold, silver, and bronze;
35.6: violet, purple, and scarlet yarn; fine linen and goat hair;
35.7: rams’ skins dyed red, and tahash skins; acacia wood;
35.8: oil for the light; spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense;
35.9: onyx stones and other gems for mounting on the ephod and on the breastpiece.
35.10: Call for Artisans. “Let every artisan among you come and make all that the LORD has commanded:
35.11: the tabernacle, with its tent, its covering, its clasps, its frames, its bars, its columns, and its pedestals;
35.12: the ark, with its poles, the cover, and the curtain veil;
35.13: the table, with its poles and all its utensils, and the showbread;
35.14: the menorah, with its utensils, the lamps, and the oil for the light;
35.15: the altar of incense, with its poles; the anointing oil, and the fragrant incense; the entrance curtain for the entrance of the tabernacle;
35.16: the altar for burnt offerings, with its bronze grating, its poles, and all its utensils; the basin, with its stand;
35.17: the hangings of the court, with their columns and pedestals; the curtain for the gate of the court;
35.18: the tent pegs for the tabernacle and for the court, with their ropes;
35.19: the service cloths for use in the sanctuary; the sacred vestments for Aaron, the priest, and the vestments for his sons in their ministry.”
35.20: The Contribution. When the whole Israelite community left Moses’ presence,
35.21: all, as their hearts moved them and their spirit prompted, brought a contribution to the LORD for the work of the tent of meeting, for all its services, and for the sacred vestments.
35.22: Both the men and the women, all as their heart prompted them, brought brooches, earrings, rings, necklaces, and various other gold articles. Everyone who could presented an offering of gold to the LORD.
35.23: Everyone who happened to have violet, purple, or scarlet yarn, fine linen or goat hair, rams’ skins dyed red or tahash skins, brought them.
35.24: Whoever could make a contribution of silver or bronze offered it to the LORD; and everyone who happened to have acacia wood for any part of the work, brought it.
35.25: All the women who were expert spinners brought hand-spun violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and fine linen thread.
35.26: All the women, as their hearts and skills moved them, spun goat hair.
35.27: The tribal leaders brought onyx stones and other gems for mounting on the ephod and on the breastpiece;
35.28: as well as spices, and oil for the light, anointing oil, and fragrant incense.
35.29: Every Israelite man and woman brought to the LORD such voluntary offerings as they thought best, for the various kinds of work which the LORD, through Moses, had commanded to be done.
35.30: The Artisans. Moses said to the Israelites: “See, the LORD has singled out Bezalel, son of Uri, son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah,
35.31: and has filled him with a divine spirit of skill and understanding and knowledge in every craft:
35.32: in the production of embroidery, in making things of gold, silver, or bronze,
35.33: in cutting and mounting precious stones, in carving wood, and in every other craft.
35.34: He has also given both him and Oholiab, son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, the ability to teach others.
35.35: He has endowed them with skill to execute all types of work: engraving, embroidering, the making of variegated cloth of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and fine linen thread, weaving, and all other arts and crafts.

36.1: Chapter 36 - “Bezalel, therefore, will set to work with Oholiab and with all the artisans whom the LORD has endowed with skill and understanding in knowing how to do all the work for the service of the sanctuary, just as the LORD has commanded.”
36.2: Moses then called Bezalel and Oholiab and all the other artisans whom the LORD had endowed with skill, men whose hearts moved them to come and do the work.
36.3: They received from Moses all the contributions which the Israelites had brought for the work to be done for the sanctuary service. Still, morning after morning the people continued to bring their voluntary offerings to Moses.
36.4: Thereupon all the artisans who were doing the work for the sanctuary came from the work each was doing,
36.5: and told Moses, “The people are bringing much more than is needed to carry out the work which the LORD has commanded us to do.”
36.6: Moses, therefore, ordered a proclamation to be made throughout the camp: “Let neither man nor woman make any more contributions for the sanctuary.” So the people stopped bringing their offerings;
36.7: there was already enough at hand, and more than enough, to complete the work to be done.
36.8: The Tent Cloth and Coverings. The various artisans who were doing the work made the tabernacle with its ten sheets woven of fine linen twined, having cherubim embroidered on them with violet, purple, and scarlet yarn.
36.9: The length of each sheet was twenty-eight cubits, and the width four cubits; all the sheets were the same size.
36.10: Five of the sheets were joined together, edge to edge; and the other five sheets likewise, edge to edge.
36.11: Loops of violet yarn were made along the edge of the end sheet in the first set, and the same along the edge of the end sheet in the second set.
36.12: Fifty loops were thus put on one inner sheet, and fifty loops on the inner sheet in the other set, with the loops directly opposite each other.
36.13: Then fifty clasps of gold were made, with which the sheets were joined so that the tabernacle formed one whole.
36.14: Sheets of goat hair were also woven as a tent over the tabernacle. Eleven such sheets were made.
36.15: The length of each sheet was thirty cubits and the width four cubits; all eleven sheets were the same size.
36.16: Five of these sheets were joined into one set, and the other six sheets into another set.
36.17: Fifty loops were made along the edge of the end sheet in one set, and fifty loops along the edge of the corresponding sheet in the other set.
36.18: Fifty bronze clasps were made with which the tent was joined so that it formed one whole.
36.19: A covering for the tent was made of rams’ skins dyed red and, above that, a covering of tahash skins.
36.20: The Framework. Frames were made for the tabernacle, acacia-wood uprights.
36.21: The length of each frame was ten cubits, and the width one and a half cubits.
36.22: Each frame had two arms, fastening them one to another. In this way all the frames of the tabernacle were made.
36.23: The frames for the tabernacle were made as follows: twenty frames on the south side,
36.24: with forty silver pedestals under the twenty frames, two pedestals under each frame for its two arms;
36.25: twenty frames on the other side of the tabernacle, the north side,
36.26: with their forty silver pedestals, two pedestals under each frame.
36.27: At the rear of the tabernacle, to the west, six frames were made,
36.28: and two frames were made for the corners of the tabernacle, at its rear.
36.29: These were double at the bottom, and likewise double at the top, to the first ring. That is how both corner frames were made.
36.30: Thus, there were eight frames, with their sixteen silver pedestals, two pedestals under each frame.
36.31: Bars of acacia wood were also made, five for the frames on one side of the tabernacle,
36.32: five for those on the other side, and five for those at the rear, to the west.
36.33: The center bar, at the middle of the frames, was made to reach across from end to end.
36.34: The frames were plated with gold, and gold rings were made on them as holders for the bars, which were also plated with gold.
36.35: The Veil. The veil was made of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn, and of fine linen twined, with cherubim embroidered on it.
36.36: Four gold-plated columns of acacia wood, with gold hooks, were made for it, and four silver pedestals were cast for them.
36.37: The curtain for the entrance of the tent was made of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn, and of fine linen twined, woven in a variegated manner.
36.38: Its five columns, with their hooks as well as their capitals and bands, were plated with gold; their five pedestals were of bronze.

37.1: Chapter 37 - The Ark. Bezalel made the ark of acacia wood, two and a half cubits long, one and a half cubits wide, and one and a half cubits high.
37.2: The inside and outside were plated with gold, and a molding of gold was put around it.
37.3: Four gold rings were cast for its four supports, two rings on one side and two on the opposite side.
37.4: Poles of acacia wood were made and plated with gold;
37.5: these poles were put through the rings on the sides of the ark, for carrying it.
37.6: The cover was made of pure gold, two and a half cubits long and one and a half cubits wide.
37.7: Two cherubim of beaten gold were made for the two ends of the cover;
37.8: one cherub was at one end, the other at the other end, made of one piece with the cover, at each end.
37.9: The cherubim had their wings spread out above, sheltering the cover. They faced each other, with their faces looking toward the cover.
37.10: The Table. The table was made of acacia wood, two cubits long, a cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high.
37.11: It was plated with pure gold, and a molding of gold was put around it.
37.12: A frame a handbreadth high was also put around it, with a molding of gold around the frame.
37.13: Four rings of gold were cast for it and fastened at the four corners, one at each leg.
37.14: The rings were alongside the frame as holders for the poles to carry the table.
37.15: These poles for carrying the table were made of acacia wood and plated with gold.
37.16: The vessels that were set on the table, its plates and cups, as well as its pitchers and bowls for pouring libations, were made of pure gold.
37.17: The Menorah. The menorah was made of pure beaten gold—its shaft and branches—with its cups and knobs and petals springing directly from it.
37.18: Six branches extended from its sides, three branches on one side and three on the other.
37.19: On one branch there were three cups, shaped like almond blossoms, each with its knob and petals; on the opposite branch there were three cups, shaped like almond blossoms, each with its knob and petals; and so for the six branches that extended from the menorah.
37.20: On the menorah there were four cups, shaped like almond blossoms, with their knobs and petals.
37.21: The six branches that went out from the menorah had a knob under each pair.
37.22: The knobs and branches so sprang from it that the whole formed but a single piece of pure beaten gold.
37.23: Its seven lamps, as well as its trimming shears and trays, were made of pure gold.
37.24: A talent of pure gold was used for the menorah and its various utensils.
37.25: The Altar of Incense. The altar of incense was made of acacia wood, on a square, a cubit long, a cubit wide, and two cubits high, having horns that sprang directly from it.
37.26: Its grate on top, its walls on all four sides, and its horns were plated with pure gold; and a gold molding was put around it.
37.27: Underneath the molding gold rings were placed, two on one side and two on the opposite side, as holders for the poles used in carrying it.
37.28: The poles, too, were made of acacia wood and plated with gold.
37.29: The sacred anointing oil and the fragrant incense were prepared in their pure form by a perfumer.

38.1: Chapter 38 - The Altar for Burnt Offerings. The altar for burnt offerings was made of acacia wood, on a square, five cubits long and five cubits wide; its height was three cubits.
38.2: At the four corners horns were made that sprang directly from the altar. It was then plated with bronze.
38.3: All the utensils of the altar, the pots, shovels, basins, forks and fire pans, were likewise made of bronze.
38.4: A grating, a bronze network, was made for the altar and placed around it, on the ground, half as high as the altar itself.
38.5: Four rings were cast for the four corners of the bronze grating, as holders for the poles,
38.6: which were made of acacia wood and plated with bronze.
38.7: The poles were put through the rings on the sides of the altar for carrying it. The altar was made in the form of a hollow box.
38.8: The bronze basin, with its bronze stand, was made from the mirrors of the women who served at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
38.9: The Court of the Tabernacle. The court was made as follows. On the south side the hangings of the court were of fine linen twined, a hundred cubits long,
38.10: with twenty columns and twenty pedestals of bronze, the hooks and bands of the columns being of silver.
38.11: On the north side there were similar hangings, a hundred cubits long, with twenty columns and twenty pedestals of bronze; the hooks and bands of the columns were of silver.
38.12: On the west side there were hangings, fifty cubits long, with ten columns and ten pedestals; the hooks and bands of the columns were of silver.
38.13: On the east side the court was fifty cubits.
38.14: On one side there were hangings to the extent of fifteen cubits, with three columns and three pedestals;
38.15: on the other side, beyond the gate of the court, there were likewise hangings to the extent of fifteen cubits, with three columns and three pedestals.
38.16: The hangings on all sides of the court were woven of fine linen twined.
38.17: The pedestals of the columns were of bronze, while the hooks and bands of the columns were of silver; the capitals were silver-plated, and all the columns of the court were banded with silver.
38.18: At the gate of the court there was a variegated curtain, woven of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and of fine linen twined, twenty cubits long and five cubits wide, in keeping with the hangings of the court.
38.19: There were four columns and four pedestals of bronze for it, while their hooks were of silver, and their capitals and their bands silver-plated.
38.20: All the tent pegs for the tabernacle and for the court around it were of bronze.
38.21: Amount of Metal Used. The following is an account of the various amounts used on the tabernacle, the tabernacle of the covenant, drawn up at the command of Moses by the Levites under the direction of Ithamar, son of Aaron the priest.
38.22: However, it was Bezalel, son of Uri, son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah, who made all that the LORD commanded Moses,
38.23: and he was assisted by Oholiab, son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, who was an engraver, an embroiderer, and a weaver of variegated cloth of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and of fine linen.
38.24: All the gold used in the entire construction of the sanctuary, having previously been given as an offering, amounted to twenty-nine talents and seven hundred and thirty shekels, according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel.
38.25: The silver of those of the community who were enrolled was one hundred talents and one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five shekels, according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel;
38.26: one bekah apiece, that is, a half-shekel, according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel, was received from everyone who was enrolled, of twenty years or more, namely, six hundred and three thousand five hundred and fifty men.
38.27: One hundred talents of silver were used for casting the pedestals of the sanctuary and the pedestals of the veil, one talent for each pedestal, or one hundred talents for the one hundred pedestals.
38.28: The remaining one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five shekels were used for making the hooks on the columns, for plating the capitals, and for banding them with silver.
38.29: The bronze, given as an offering, amounted to seventy talents and two thousand four hundred shekels.
38.30: With this were made the pedestals at the entrance of the tent of meeting, the bronze altar with its bronze gratings, and all the utensils of the altar,
38.31: the pedestals around the court, the pedestals at the gate of the court, and all the tent pegs for the tabernacle and for the court around it.

39.1: Chapter 39 - The Priestly Vestments. With violet, purple, and scarlet yarn were woven the service cloths for use in the sanctuary, as well as the sacred vestments for Aaron, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.2: The ephod was woven of gold thread and of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and of fine linen twined.
39.3: Gold was first hammered into gold leaf and then cut up into threads, which were woven with the violet, purple, and scarlet yarn into an embroidered pattern on the fine linen.
39.4: Shoulder straps were made for it and joined to its two upper ends.
39.5: The embroidered belt on the ephod extended out from it, and like it, was made of gold thread, of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn, and of fine linen twined, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.6: The onyx stones were prepared and mounted in gold filigree work; they were engraved like seal engravings with the names of the sons of Israel.
39.7: These stones were set on the shoulder straps of the ephod as memorial stones of the sons of Israel, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.8: The breastpiece was embroidered like the ephod, with gold thread and violet, purple, and scarlet yarn on cloth of fine linen twined.
39.9: It was square and folded double, a span high and a span wide in its folded form.
39.10: Four rows of precious stones were mounted on it: in the first row a carnelian, a topaz, and an emerald;
39.11: in the second row, a garnet, a sapphire, and a beryl;
39.12: in the third row a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst;
39.13: in the fourth row a chrysolite, an onyx, and a jasper. They were mounted in gold filigree work.
39.14: These stones were twelve, to match the names of the sons of Israel, and each stone was engraved like a seal with the name of one of the twelve tribes.
39.15: Chains of pure gold, twisted like cords, were made for the breastpiece,
39.16: together with two gold filigree rosettes and two gold rings. The two rings were fastened to the two upper ends of the breastpiece.
39.17: The two gold chains were then fastened to the two rings at the ends of the breastpiece.
39.18: The other two ends of the two chains were fastened in front to the two filigree rosettes, which were attached to the shoulder straps of the ephod.
39.19: Two other gold rings were made and put on the two lower ends of the breastpiece, on the edge facing the ephod.
39.20: Two more gold rings were made and fastened to the bottom of the two shoulder straps next to where they joined the ephod in front, just above its embroidered belt.
39.21: Violet ribbons bound the rings of the breastpiece to the rings of the ephod, so that the breastpiece stayed right above the embroidered belt of the ephod and did not swing loose from it. All this was just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.22: Other Vestments. The robe of the ephod was woven entirely of violet yarn,
39.23: with an opening in its center like the opening of a shirt, with selvage around the opening to keep it from being torn.
39.24: At the hem of the robe pomegranates were made of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn and of fine linen twined;
39.25: bells of pure gold were also made and put between the pomegranates all around the hem of the robe:
39.26: a bell, a pomegranate, a bell, a pomegranate, all around the hem of the robe which was to be worn in performing the ministry—all this, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.27: For Aaron and his sons there were also woven tunics of fine linen;
39.28: the turban of fine linen; the ornate skullcaps of fine linen; linen pants of fine linen twined;
39.29: and sashes of variegated work made of fine linen twined and of violet, purple, and scarlet yarn, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.30: The plate of the sacred diadem was made of pure gold and inscribed, as on a seal engraving: “Sacred to the LORD.”
39.31: It was tied over the turban with a violet ribbon, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.32: Presentation of the Work to Moses. Thus the entire work of the tabernacle of the tent of meeting was completed. The Israelites did the work just as the LORD had commanded Moses; so it was done.
39.33: They then brought to Moses the tabernacle, the tent with all its furnishings, the clasps, the frames, the bars, the columns, the pedestals,
39.34: the covering of rams’ skins dyed red, the covering of tahash skins, the curtain veil;
39.35: the ark of the covenant with its poles, the cover,
39.36: the table with all its utensils and the showbread,
